statement.text: Brachial artery exposure is performed through an incision along the medial arm or in the antecubital fossa, with the artery lying superficial between the biceps and triceps muscles accompanied by the median nerve and brachial veins.
statement.formal: Brachial_Exposure: Medial_Arm_Incision → Between_Biceps/Triceps → Artery + Median_Nerve + Veins

explanation.intuition: The brachial artery is the main blood supply to your forearm. It runs down the inside of your upper arm alongside a major nerve (median). To access it, you make an incision on the inner arm and find it between the two main arm muscles.
explanation.key_insight: The median nerve crosses from lateral to medial over the brachial artery in the mid-arm. At the antecubital fossa, the artery bifurcates into radial and ulnar arteries beneath the bicipital aponeurosis.
explanation.technical_details: Upper arm: incision along medial biceps groove, artery between biceps (anterior) and triceps (posterior), median nerve initially lateral then crosses to medial. Antecubital fossa: S-shaped incision crossing elbow crease, divide bicipital aponeurosis (lacertus fibrosus), identify bifurcation into radial (lateral) and ulnar (medial) arteries. Nerve relationships: median nerve - medial; musculocutaneous nerve - lateral under biceps; ulnar nerve - posterior, in groove. Common access site for retrograde cardiac catheterization.

procedural_details.key_structure: Bicipital aponeurosis (lacertus fibrosus) overlies vessels at elbow
procedural_details.bifurcation: Radial artery (lateral) and ulnar artery (medial) at antecubital fossa

nerve_relationships.median: Initially lateral, crosses to medial in mid-arm

clinical_pearls: Median nerve crosses brachial artery from lateral to medial in mid-arm
Bicipital aponeurosis must be divided for antecubital exposure
Brachial artery is preferred access for retrograde cardiac catheterization
